description: Accounting is the process of collecting, recording, classifying, summarizing and reporting the financial dealings of a business, organization or individual. Businesses must maintain accurate and timely accounting records to measure their economic performance, satisfy reporting requirements and make sound financial decisions. Accountants are essential in every industry, providing services in financial management, auditing, taxation and forensic accounting. With a bachelor's degree in accounting, you'll be prepared for careers as diverse as auditing, corporate accounting, tax preparation, risk management, financial planning and forensic accounting. In addition, an accounting degree is excellent preparation for law school and an MBA. Accounting majors at Baylor acquire a broad understanding of the functional areas of business and the accounting profession while developing effective critical thinking, analytical, problem-solving, and communication skills. Students apply theory to practice through experiential learning and case studies, gaining the necessary skills and professional judgment to succeed in a wide variety of accounting and business careers.
Accreditation status: Accredited by the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business (AACSB International).
Program name: Bachelor of Business Administration in Accounting

Accreditation status: The Department of Journalism, Public Relations, and New Media is accredited by the Accrediting Council on Education in Journalism and Mass Communications (ACEJMC).
Program name: Minor in Advertising

description: The Department of Mechanical Engineering and the Department of Electrical & Computer Engineering at Baylor University collaborate to offer the Bachelor of Science in Aerospace Engineering. Students are taught aerospace engineering foundations while focusing on design and integration of aerospace systems. The program provides the intellectual foundation for those entering the aerospace industry, defense industry, space exploration or graduate study. Graduates are prepared for careers in manned and unmanned aircraft, rotorcraft, and spacecraft development and operations; aerospace product sales, marketing, and management; and more.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Aerospace Engineering

description: The Aerospace Studies minor will expose students to leadership fundamentals through experiential learning and the study of aerospace history, national security policy, and space operations. The curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, problem-solving, effective communication, and ethical decision-making. These skills are essential for future leaders and are highly valued in both military and civilian careers. In addition to gaining a comprehensive understanding of aerospace studies, students will also develop a strong sense of discipline, teamwork, and social responsibility. This minor will prepare students for leadership roles in various fields, including military service, government, and industry.
Program name: Minor in Aerospace Studies

description: The American Sign Language Minor requires a minimum of 18 credit hours and is housed in the Department of Communication Sciences and Disorders. This Minor will help students develop a foundational knowledge of ASL and Deaf culture, which can enhance any major by developing an understanding of diversity, language acquisition, and communication differences. The minor helps prepare students to work with the Deaf community and also satisfy language requirements for graduate schools or professional schools (Law school, Medical school, etc.).
Program name: Minor in American Sign Language

description: Do you want to study American culture from a variety of perspectives? The American Studies program lets you explore the many dimensions of the American experience, including its history, literature, politics, religion, fine arts, and popular culture. The program provides the knowledge and critical thinking skills to prepare you for a wide range of graduate programs and careers, including law, journalism, public history, education, and museum studies. The American Studies major is an interdisciplinary program that allows students to explore American culture from multiple perspectives, including its history, literature, religion, fine arts, political science, and sociology. As a student, you will have the opportunity to take courses from a variety of departments, providing you with a broad understanding of the American experience.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in American Studies

description: The study of anthropology aims to provide an understanding of human experience and the human condition both past and present through cultural, archaeological, biological, and linguistic approaches. By examining humanity's diverse forms of social organization and meaning-making, anthropology seeks to promote an informed appreciation of differences in human cultures and societies, and an understanding of the relationship between local and global issues. As an academic discipline, anthropology is committed to interdisciplinary and holistic perspectives regarding humans, their institutions, and the environment. This commitment, in turn, supports Baylor's mission by fostering broad scholarship and promoting responsible citizenship that serves global communities. Through its courses and curriculum, the Anthropology program emphasizes critical thinking and communication skills, cultural and ethical reasoning, and qualitative and quantitative research methods.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Anthropology
Bachelor of Science in Anthropology

description: The Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Apparel Design & Product Development prepares students for careers in the global apparel industry. Students will gain knowledge of apparel design, product development, production, merchandising, and entrepreneurship. The curriculum combines coursework in apparel, business, and fine arts. Students gain hands-on experience in garment construction, computer-aided design, textile science, product lifecycle management, global sourcing, and retail strategies. Emphasis is placed on ethical and sustainable practices within the fashion supply chain. Graduates are prepared for roles such as apparel designers, product developers, merchandisers, buyers, and entrepreneurs in various sectors of the apparel industry.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Apparel Design & Product Development

description: The Minor in Apparel Merchandising provides an overview of the apparel industry and equips students with an understanding of key apparel merchandising components and professional functions. The curriculum exposes students to a variety of topics within apparel design and merchandising, including apparel product development, textile science, apparel manufacturing, visual merchandising, and buying and selling. Students develop knowledge and skills to successfully work in global apparel and retail industries. Students must earn a grade of “C” or better in all courses counted toward the minor.
Program name: Minor in Apparel Merchandising

description: The Bachelor of Science in Applied Mathematics focuses on mathematical modeling, computational methods, and analysis of real-world problems. It is designed for students interested in careers in scientific computing, data science, engineering, or graduate studies in applied mathematics or related fields.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Applied Mathematics

description: A minor in Arabic consists of a minimum of 18 semester hours beyond the first two semesters of Arabic (ARA 1301-1302). It is designed to provide students with the ability to communicate and understand Arabic, as well as an appreciation for the peoples and cultures where it is spoken. Studying Arabic also provides an avenue for students to develop an understanding of Islamic traditions and cultures.
Program name: Minor in Arabic

description: The Bachelor of Arts in Arabic and Middle East Studies (AMES) at Baylor University provides students with a thorough grounding in the Arabic language, as well as an interdisciplinary understanding of the complex history, cultures, politics, and religions of the Middle East. Through rigorous language instruction, coursework in diverse fields, and opportunities for study abroad, students develop critical thinking, communication, and cross-cultural competencies essential for careers in government, international relations, non-governmental organizations, business, journalism, and academia. The program emphasizes both classical and modern Arabic, equipping graduates with a versatile linguistic foundation, and prepares them for advanced study or professional engagement in a globally interconnected world.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Arabic and Middle East Studies

description: An Archaeology minor requires 18 semester hours from the list of approved courses. A minimum of nine semester hours must be advanced, and a minimum of nine semester hours must be taken in residence. Students must complete at least 15 semester hours in the College of Arts & Sciences. No more than nine semester hours may be counted from a student’s major. No courses taken to satisfy the minor requirements may be taken Pass/Fail. For more information, please visit the Department of History, Dr. Julie Sweet.
Program name: Minor in Archaeology

description: The Bachelor of Arts with a major in Art History is a liberal arts degree emphasizing a broad and deep study of the history of art and architecture, from antiquity to the present. The program is designed to provide students with a strong foundation in visual analysis and critical thinking, encouraging them to engage with art and its historical, cultural, and theoretical contexts. Through a rigorous curriculum encompassing various periods and cultures, students develop research skills, communication abilities, and a nuanced understanding of art’s role in human experience. The program prepares students for a wide range of career paths, including graduate studies in art history, museum work, gallery management, art conservation, arts administration, teaching, and other fields requiring critical analysis and visual literacy.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Art History

description: The Art History minor gives students an opportunity to study art in its cultural and historical contexts. As they develop visual literacy and critical thinking skills, students are prepared to conduct historical and theoretical analysis of various artistic traditions. Such skills are invaluable in careers in museums, galleries, auction houses, publishing, education, and the legal profession, among others. An Art History minor prepares students for graduate study in art history as well as professional careers in arts administration, collections management, preservation, conservation, education, and art librarianship.
Program name: Minor in Art History

description: The Bachelor of Arts in Asian Studies is an interdisciplinary degree that enables students to gain comprehensive knowledge of Asian cultures, histories, and societies. Students completing the degree will possess strong analytical and critical thinking skills, as well as an understanding of the region's diverse political, economic, and social systems. The program emphasizes language acquisition and cultural immersion, preparing students for a wide range of careers in international relations, business, education, and public service. Graduates will be equipped to engage with global challenges and opportunities related to Asia and contribute meaningfully to an increasingly interconnected world.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Asian Studies

description: The minor in Asian Studies provides students with an interdisciplinary understanding of the languages, cultures, histories, religions, economies, and political systems of Asia. The program promotes an appreciation of Asian diversity through a curriculum that draws on the expertise of faculty in anthropology, art history, history, modern languages and cultures, political science, and religion. Students pursuing a minor in Asian Studies will be exposed to a broad array of cultures, traditions, and ideas and will be prepared for a wide range of graduate studies and professional careers.
Program name: Minor in Asian Studies
Bachelor of Arts in Astronomy

description: The Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Astronomy is designed for students who desire a stronger mathematical and physical science background than is normally part of a B.A. degree. Students in the B.S. program will have a sufficiently strong background to be accepted into graduate programs in astronomy or astrophysics. In addition to a rigorous training in astronomy, students will take a strong sequence of mathematics, physics, and computer science courses as part of their major. Baylor University offers both the Bachelor of Arts (BA) and Bachelor of Science (BS) degrees in Astronomy. Our programs provide students with a strong foundation in physics and mathematics, preparing them for graduate studies or careers in research, education, or industry. Through rigorous coursework, hands-on research opportunities, and state-of-the-art facilities, students gain a deep understanding of the universe, from planets and stars to galaxies and cosmology.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Astronomy

description: The study of astrophysics merges principles of physics with the exploration of celestial objects and phenomena. Through courses in physics, mathematics, and astronomy, students gain a comprehensive understanding of the universe, from the smallest particles to the largest galaxies. They delve into topics such as stellar evolution, cosmology, galactic dynamics, and observational astronomy. The program emphasizes critical thinking, problem-solving, and scientific inquiry, preparing students for research, graduate studies, or careers in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields. This program is excellent preparation for careers as professional astronomers and astrophysicists in academia or industry. Students will gain knowledge and skills in understanding the physical mechanisms and fundamental principles that govern the Universe, scientific research methodology including computational and laboratory experience, and the ability to critically analyze and communicate scientific data and research findings.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Astrophysics

description: Baylor's Department of Physics offers a Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Astrophysics to students interested in understanding the structure and evolution of the universe. This program combines rigorous coursework in physics with specialized courses in astrophysics, observational techniques, and theoretical models. Students will gain a deep understanding of celestial mechanics, stellar physics, galaxies, cosmology, and the tools and methods used in astrophysical research. The curriculum prepares students for graduate studies in astrophysics or related fields, as well as careers in research, education, or technology industries.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Astrophysics

description: The Bachelor of Science in Aviation Administration is an interdisciplinary degree intended for students who wish to pursue a career in the aviation industry. In addition to a core curriculum of 30 hours, students complete 27 hours of aviation courses, 15 hours of business courses and 9 hours of flight science courses for a total of 81 major hours. Students completing this degree will be qualified for a wide variety of aviation-related career paths including airline management, airport management, fixed base operations (FBO) management, corporate aviation, aviation real estate, aviation insurance, aircraft sales, or aviation consulting.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Aviation Administration

Concentration name: Professional Pilot, Aircraft Dispatch, Aviation Administration
description:
The Bachelor of Science in Aviation Sciences program provides students with the foundational knowledge and skills required to pursue careers in the dynamic aviation industry. Students gain a comprehensive understanding of aviation principles, operations, safety regulations, and management. This degree prepares graduates for various roles within airlines, corporate aviation, government agencies, and other aviation-related organizations.

As an Aviation Sciences major, you’ll take courses in areas such as:

Aviation History
Aviation Weather
Air Traffic Control
Aviation Law
Aircraft Systems
Aerodynamics
Aviation Safety
Aviation Management
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Aviation Sciences
Bachelor of Arts in Biochemistry
Bachelor of Science in Biochemistry

description: Bioinformatics is an interdisciplinary field that uses computational approaches to understand and interpret biological data. Students who pursue a Minor in Bioinformatics will gain a strong foundation in both the biological sciences and computer science, learning to analyze and visualize complex biological data sets. This minor prepares students for careers in research, industry, and healthcare, where the ability to manage and interpret large biological data is increasingly critical.
Program name: Minor in Bioinformatics

description: The Department of Biology offers an undergraduate program of study leading to the Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) in Biology. The curriculum for the Bachelor of Arts is a less intensive course of study than the Bachelor of Science, as it requires fewer semester hours in the major field of study. It is designed for students who desire a broad liberal arts education with a strong scientific background or for students who wish to pursue a second major in a non-science discipline, such as foreign language, pre-seminary studies, political science, or journalism. Graduates with the B.A. in biology often continue their education in graduate school, medical school, dental school, or other health-related professional schools.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Biology

description: The Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Biology at Baylor is designed to provide you with a broad background in all areas of biology, including microbiology, cellular and molecular biology, ecology, evolution and anatomy, and physiology. This major gives you a firm foundation in science to pursue a wide range of career paths, from medicine and dentistry to research, teaching and environmental science. It is an ideal major if you are seeking a career in the health professions and is the most common path for those pursuing advanced degrees in medicine and other health fields.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Biology

description: The minor in Business Administration is available to students who are not pursuing a major in the Hankamer School of Business and wish to develop a general understanding of business concepts. The minor consists of eighteen hours of coursework. All courses for the minor must be completed with a minimum grade of "C" and with a minimum 2.0 GPA in the minor. Students must also maintain an overall 2.75 GPA to remain in the minor. No more than two courses may be transferred from another institution. No course for the minor may be taken on a pass/fail basis. Students who are majoring in the Hankamer School of Business may not declare the Business Administration minor. This minor is not available to students majoring in Business Journalism.
Program name: Minor in Business Administration

description: The Business Fellows program is a highly selective honors program that provides outstanding business students with an interdisciplinary course of study, enhanced opportunities for faculty interaction, and academic experiences tailored to their professional interests and career goals. Business Fellows attracts students who are seeking a rigorous, challenging academic experience, and who plan to integrate the liberal arts into their business education. The program is specifically designed to allow students to complete a rigorous business degree, a minor in a non-business field of their choice, and the full Business Fellows core within four years. Business Fellows majors also complete the requirements for a BBA degree in Business Administration.
Accreditation status: The Hankamer School of Business is accredited by the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business (AACSB) International. AACSB accreditation is the hallmark of excellence in business education, and has been earned by less than five percent of the world's business programs.
Program name: Bachelor of Business Administration in Business Fellows
Bachelor of Arts in Chemistry

description: This major is designed for students who desire a career in chemistry or a related field, or who desire preparation for graduate school or professional school (medicine, dentistry, veterinary medicine, physical therapy, law, etc.). Students in this program are expected to carry out undergraduate research and present their research at scientific meetings. This major is certified by the American Chemical Society.
Accreditation status: Certified by the American Chemical Society.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Chemistry

description: A minor in Chemistry provides foundational instruction in general, organic, and physical chemistry. The minor consists of 20 hours of chemistry courses that provide a solid background for students in other science disciplines, such as biology, forensic science, geology, environmental studies, or pre-health, who desire a deeper understanding of chemical principles.
Program name: Minor in Chemistry

description: As part of the Robbins College of Health and Human Sciences, the Bachelor of Science in Child and Family Studies prepares students for careers in community and social service agencies, hospitals, early childhood intervention programs, child advocacy programs, and government agencies. This program provides students with the academic foundation to pursue graduate studies in child and family studies, social work, counseling, public health, and other related fields. Students gain extensive experience through required practicum and internship experiences in settings such as hospitals, schools, and non-profit organizations. Students can select one of two concentrations to help focus their studies. The Child Development concentration is designed to meet the requirements of the Certified Child Life Specialist (CCLS) exam, and prepares students for careers in child life, early childhood development, and related fields. The Family Life Education concentration meets the academic requirements for provisional certification as a Certified Family Life Educator (CFLE), and prepares students for careers that help strengthen families.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Child and Family Studies

description:
The Chinese program offers courses in language, literature, and culture. A diverse faculty provides comprehensive instruction in all areas. Our goal is to provide students with a solid foundation in the Chinese language and culture so they can excel in graduate school, careers, or further language studies. Opportunities exist for study abroad in China or Taiwan, interaction with native speakers on campus, and participation in various cultural events.

A minor in Chinese consists of 18 semester hours (6 advanced). Students may select from any courses in Chinese language, literature, or culture beyond CHI 1402. Six hours of the 18 hours must be at the 3000-4000 level. Students who begin study beyond CHI 1301 because of previous experience in the language must complete 18 semester hours of Chinese courses at their level of entrance and above. No more than 6 hours of CHI 1000 level courses may count toward the minor.
Program name: Minor in Chinese

description: Our Chinese Language and Culture BA offers students the opportunity to learn Chinese language, culture, and literature in a holistic and engaging way. Students in the program develop communicative competency in Chinese, learning to speak, write, and comprehend the language at an advanced level. By learning the Chinese language and engaging with Chinese culture, students in the program gain critical intercultural competency, preparing them for a wide array of careers in a globalized world. At Baylor, we believe that learning Chinese goes beyond the classroom, offering students opportunities to study abroad, connect with community, and engage in meaningful research. Many students combine their Chinese Language and Culture major with another major or minor, such as political science, history, international studies, pre-law, or business. Upon graduation, our students pursue careers in government, business, education, or they continue their education in graduate school.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Chinese Language and Culture

description: The Minor in Christianity and the Arts, housed in the Department of Religion, is a 18-hour interdisciplinary program that enables students to pursue their interest in the relationship between religious faith and artistic expression. Students will engage questions regarding the history, theory, and practice of Christian art in its various forms. The minor is offered in conjunction with the Department of Art and Art History, the School of Music, and the Department of English. This Minor provides excellent preparation for graduate work in these fields, or for careers in arts management, museology, and church vocations. It can also complement any major by enabling students to reflect on the nature of creativity, the role of art in Christian life, and the importance of critical understanding for the production and reception of art.
Program name: Minor in Chistianity and Arts

description: The Bachelor of Music Education (B.M.E.) is designed for students who desire a comprehensive musical background and are seeking certification to teach music in public schools. Students may select a specialization in either Choral Music Education or Instrumental Music Education. Upon graduation, students are eligible to apply for the Texas All-Level Music Certificate.
Program name: Bachelor of Music Education in Choral Music

description: This degree program is designed to develop students in the areas of worship, conducting, composition, and keyboard skills while giving them a solid foundation in music theory, history, and literature. They are prepared to assume leadership positions in local churches and para-church ministries across the country and around the world, as well as to pursue graduate studies in church music, worship studies, conducting, and composition. The program offers a solid core of academic and music courses, including electives, to provide a well-rounded education. Students are offered a wide range of performance opportunities and ensembles, including university choirs, instrumental ensembles, opera, and chamber groups. Faculty members are active performers, composers, scholars, and church musicians.
Accreditation status: Accredited by the National Association of Schools of Music (NASM)
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Church Music

Concentration name: Vocal Studies, Organ Studies, Worship Leadership Studies
description: Welcome to Church Music at Baylor University! The Church Music program is housed within the nationally recognized School of Music and is home to the most comprehensive degree program in church music among institutions of its kind in the United States. The Bachelor of Music in Church Music is designed to prepare students for positions of leadership in music ministries of local churches, parachurch organizations, denominational agencies, and in specialized areas of worship and arts ministry. This rigorous program provides a solid foundation in music theory, history, and performance, coupled with specialized training in church music history, theology, worship leadership, and practical ministry skills. Graduates are equipped with the musical excellence and theological understanding necessary to lead vibrant and impactful worship experiences in diverse congregational settings.
Program name: Bachelor of Music in Church Music

description: The Civic Interfaith Studies Minor is housed in the Diana R. Garland School of Social Work, and offers students the opportunity to explore religion and spirituality through an interdisciplinary lens, with a particular focus on how religious and non-religious people engage with each other for the common good. Courses in the minor focus on understanding diverse religious perspectives, developing skills for interfaith engagement, and applying interfaith principles to contemporary social issues. The minor aims to equip students with the knowledge and competencies necessary to navigate a religiously pluralistic world and contribute positively to their communities through respectful dialogue and collaborative action. This minor is open to all Baylor students who wish to deepen their understanding of interfaith relations and develop practical skills for promoting peace and social justice in a diverse society.
Program name: Minor in Civic Interfaith Studies

description: The Bachelor of Arts in Classics (BA in Classics) provides a comprehensive introduction to the languages, literature, history, and archaeology of ancient Greece and Rome. Students develop linguistic proficiency in either Latin or Greek (or both), explore the foundational texts of Western thought and culture, and engage with the material remains of the ancient world. The program emphasizes critical thinking, analytical skills, and a deep understanding of the classical tradition's enduring influence on contemporary society.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Classics

description:
The Classics minor encourages students to develop a greater understanding and appreciation of the ancient Greeks and Romans. Through study of their language, literature, culture, history, art, and archaeology, students will gain valuable insight into the roots of Western civilization.
The minor requires 18 hours including:

*   Latin or Greek through the intermediate level (6 hours)
*   CLAS 2300 (3 hours)
*   CLAS 3300 (3 hours)
*   6 hours of additional CLAS courses above 1000 level
Program name: Minor in Classics

description: Baylor's Department of Communication teaches students to understand and practice effective communication in a variety of contexts through research-based and theory-driven instruction. Communication majors develop skills in oral, written, visual, and mediated communication, preparing them for a variety of careers or for graduate study. This major is offered as a Bachelor of Arts (BA) in the College of Arts & Sciences.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Communication
Minor in Communication

description: The Bachelor of Science in Communication Sciences and Disorders is a professional degree providing the undergraduate student with knowledge in the normal processes of speech, language, and hearing; the development of those processes; and the nature of the disorders of communication. The program focuses on understanding the scientific bases of communication sciences and disorders, as well as the diagnostic and therapeutic principles for treating individuals with communication disorders. Graduates are prepared to pursue a Master of Science in Communication Sciences and Disorders. Many courses also fulfill prerequisites for graduate study in audiology. The curriculum provides a strong liberal arts background, with supporting coursework in natural sciences, social sciences, and mathematics. Students are provided opportunities for clinical observation hours and research experience.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Communication Sciences and Disorders
Bachelor of Arts in Communication Specialist

description: The Bachelor of Music in Composition is designed for students who demonstrate exceptional talent and potential in musical composition. Students will develop a strong foundation in music theory, history, and aural skills, while simultaneously honing their compositional craft through individual lessons, seminars, and practical application. The curriculum emphasizes creative exploration, critical thinking, and the development of a unique artistic voice. Graduates are prepared for further study at the graduate level, careers in composition, or related fields in music. This rigorous program provides students with a broad curriculum in core musicianship, music history, and music theory, in addition to coursework in composition, orchestration, and counterpoint. Students have numerous opportunities for collaboration with student and faculty performers in a wide variety of ensembles and contexts, including the Baylor Symphony Orchestra, Wind Ensemble, A Cappella Choir, and various chamber groups. All students will participate in an annual Composition Department concert, showcasing their original works. The degree culminates in a senior recital featuring original compositions.
Program name: Bachelor of Music in Composition

description: A Computer Engineer is a specialist in the design, construction, and application of computing devices and systems, from microprocessors to embedded computing systems to supercomputers. Students graduating with a B.S. in Computer Engineering from Baylor will have a broad background in topics like digital system design, computer architecture, embedded systems, software engineering, and computer networking. Computer Engineering is a dynamic field, and the curriculum at Baylor is designed to be highly flexible, allowing students to focus on areas of interest by pursuing electives in areas like machine learning, cybersecurity, biomedical applications, and more.
Accreditation status: The Electrical and Computer Engineering programs at Baylor University are accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, www.abet.org.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Computer Engineering

description: The Computer Science BA degree program provides a solid foundation in computer science through a curriculum that emphasizes liberal arts perspectives. This degree allows students to combine computer science with other interests, such as a double major in another field or preparing for professional schools in law or medicine. This curriculum also has a strong emphasis on writing and foreign language proficiency.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Computer Science

description: The Bachelor of Science in Computer Science (BSCS) program provides students with a strong theoretical and practical foundation in computer science and prepares them for further graduate study or for a wide variety of computing-related careers. The curriculum is designed to give students foundational knowledge in areas such as programming languages, algorithms, data structures, computer architecture, and software engineering. Graduates will develop critical problem-solving skills, an understanding of complex computational systems, and the ability to design, implement, and analyze software solutions effectively. The program also emphasizes ethical considerations in computing and prepares students to be responsible and innovative contributors to the field.
Accreditation status: Accredited by the Computing Accreditation Commission of ABET.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Computer Science
Bachelor of Science in Computer Science Fellows

description: The Corporate Communication Minor equips students to understand and apply communication strategies in a variety of organizational settings. Students will develop skills in written and oral communication, critical thinking, problem solving, and ethical decision-making, preparing them for careers in corporate, non-profit, and governmental organizations.
Program name: Minor in Corporate Communication

description: The Minor in Creative Writing offers students the opportunity to develop their imaginative and expressive talents, sharpen their critical judgment, and develop an understanding of the craft of writing. Students may pursue courses in fiction, poetry, screenwriting, and creative nonfiction. The Minor is suitable for students in any discipline who wish to hone their creative skills. Courses allow students to explore different genres, experiment with various forms and styles, and receive constructive feedback on their work in a workshop setting. The minor culminates in a capstone course that allows students to focus on a particular genre and develop a substantial portfolio of creative work.
Program name: Minor in Creative Writing

description: The criminal justice minor provides students with a general knowledge of the American criminal justice system. The minor provides an interdisciplinary exploration of crime, criminal behavior, and the components of the justice system and its related issues. The minor is appropriate for students interested in careers in law enforcement, courts, corrections, and related fields (e.g., social work, forensics, public administration) as well as those pursuing graduate studies in criminal justice, law, and other social science disciplines. Through coursework, students will learn about the history, structure, and functions of the criminal justice system as well as about criminal behavior and relevant social, economic, and political issues. The minor also offers students the opportunity to examine issues related to justice and public policy in the American context. The courses required for the minor provide a foundational understanding for continued study and exploration.
Program name: Minor in Criminal Justice

description: The Cybersecurity Minor provides students with fundamental knowledge, skills, and abilities necessary to understand and apply cybersecurity principles and practices. This minor is open to all students at Baylor University regardless of major and is available from the Department of Computer Science. Through the interdisciplinary minor, students are exposed to the multiple facets of cybersecurity by taking courses from the following departments: Computer Science, Accounting & Business Law, and Electrical & Computer Engineering.
Program name: Minor in Cybersecurity

description: As a dance minor, you will learn the fundamentals of technique, theory, and choreography in an enriching and supportive environment. This program focuses on developing dancers who are well-rounded intellectually and physically, and provides a strong foundation for continued study in dance or for a lifetime of engagement with the art form. Opportunities for performance and choreography are offered each semester through faculty and student showcases.
Program name: Minor in Dance

description: The Bachelor of Science in Data Science is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students foundational knowledge in three core areas: Mathematics, Computer Science, and Statistical Science. Data Science is the study of data from its collection and storage to its analysis and communication. It draws on tools and techniques from statistics, computer science, and mathematics to make sense of large, complex data sets. Data Science has emerged as a new field driven by the increase in the volume of data available across diverse fields and industries. This degree program prepares students to use modern computational and statistical tools to analyze and interpret large and complex data in preparation for further study or entry-level careers in data science. Students gain extensive training in mathematics, statistics, and computer science. The curriculum includes courses in calculus, linear algebra, probability, statistics, data structures, algorithms, machine learning, and database management.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Data Science

description: Data Science is an interdisciplinary field focused on extracting knowledge and insights from data. It combines elements of statistics, computer science, and domain-specific knowledge to analyze and interpret complex datasets. The Minor in Data Science is designed to provide students with a foundational understanding of data science principles and techniques. Students will learn how to collect, clean, analyze, and visualize data, as well as apply statistical models and machine learning algorithms to solve real-world problems. The minor emphasizes practical skills and hands-on experience, preparing students for careers in data analysis, business intelligence, and related fields, or for further graduate study.
Program name: Minor in Data Science

description: A Bachelor of Arts (BA) degree in Earth Science prepares students for careers in geology, environmental science, and other related fields. The BA degree is more flexible than the BS degree and allows students to pursue a second major or minor, or to take more elective courses. The BA degree focuses on the liberal arts and humanities, providing students with a broad education in addition to their scientific knowledge.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Earth Science
Bachelor of Arts in Economics

description: The Bachelor of Business Administration in Economics program provides students with a strong foundation in economic theory, quantitative methods, and analytical skills. Students learn to analyze market trends, evaluate economic policies, and understand the forces that shape global economies. This rigorous curriculum prepares graduates for careers in business, finance, government, and various other fields where critical thinking and data analysis are paramount. Students also gain a solid understanding of business principles, making them well-rounded professionals capable of making informed decisions in complex economic environments.
Program name: Bachelor of Business Administration in Economics

description: An economist considers the most efficient way to allocate scarce resources. Economics is not just about money, it’s about a vast range of human choice and interaction. Economics teaches a different way of thinking that is highly valued in the marketplace because it emphasizes clear, analytical thought, and strong quantitative skills. The major in Economics (BS) is for students who want to develop strong quantitative skills that are applicable in a wide range of analytical areas. It prepares students for graduate work in economics, law, or business and provides excellent training for careers in business, government, or finance. The BS in Economics requires completion of more quantitative coursework than the BA in Economics. All Economics majors are housed in the Department of Economics in the Hankamer School of Business.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Economics

description: The B.S.Ed. in Elementary Education prepares students to be caring, competent, and highly qualified teachers for grades Early Childhood (EC) through 6th grade. Students completing the program are eligible for the Core Subjects EC-6 and the English as a Second Language (ESL) supplemental certifications in Texas. The curriculum is specifically designed to meet current state teaching certification requirements for Core Subjects EC-6 and ESL supplemental certification. Students are placed in a variety of public school settings throughout the professional development sequence which provides extensive clinical teaching experiences. Through their coursework and clinical experiences, students will develop competencies in areas such as planning, instruction, content knowledge, managing the learning environment, technology, assessment, and professional responsibility. Our graduates are highly sought after by school districts across Texas and the nation.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Education - Elementary Education
Bachelor of Science in Education - Middle Grade English, Language Arts, and Reading

description: Are you interested in a career in teaching? With a Bachelor of Science in Education (B.S.Ed.) in Middle Grade Mathematics, you will be prepared to teach mathematics in grades 4-8. Students who complete the middle grade mathematics program at Baylor University will develop an advanced understanding of the mathematical content and pedagogical knowledge required to teach middle school mathematics. With a focus on learning through inquiry, problem solving, and hands-on experiences, this program will help you learn how to effectively teach mathematics to middle school students. You’ll become a part of the Baylor School of Education family and join an extensive network of alumni teaching mathematics in middle schools and school districts across Texas and the United States.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Education - Middle Grade Mathematics

description: The Bachelor of Science in Education (B.S.Ed.) program at Baylor University’s School of Education prepares students to become highly effective and compassionate teachers in various educational settings. Our program emphasizes a comprehensive understanding of educational theories, practical teaching methodologies, and a commitment to fostering a positive learning environment. Students will gain hands-on experience through practicums and student teaching, ensuring they are well-prepared to meet the diverse needs of learners. Graduates are equipped with the knowledge, skills, and dispositions to inspire and make a lasting impact on their students’ lives. Middle Grades Education prepares students to teach in grades 4-8. Students in this program typically choose two subject areas to teach, allowing them to specialize and cater to the unique developmental needs of pre-adolescent learners. This certification track provides an in-depth understanding of curriculum development, instructional strategies, and classroom management techniques specific to the middle school environment.
Accreditation status: The Educator Preparation Program at Baylor University is accredited by the Texas Education Agency (TEA) and has been approved by the State Board for Educator Certification (SBEC) since 1916. In 2021, the Educator Preparation Program was awarded accreditation by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP) under the CAEP Standards for Advanced Programs.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Education - Middle Grade Science

description: The Baylor School of Education prepares teachers for Texas public and private schools, as well as for school districts throughout the nation. Middle Grades (4-8) programs lead to a Bachelor of Science in Education (B.S.Ed.) degree and eligibility for teacher certification in grades 4-8. Students choose two academic specialization areas (with a Social Studies specialization available as a single teaching field option). The Social Studies 4-8 program offers students a wide range of social sciences including history, geography, government, and economics. You will learn to teach students to think critically and to apply the knowledge of the past to the present and future.
Accreditation status: Fully accredited by the State Board for Educator Certification (SBEC) and the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP)
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Education - Middle Grade Social Studies

Concentration name: Secondary English, Language Arts, and Reading
description: The secondary English, language arts, and reading program prepares candidates to teach grades 9-12 in an area that includes literature, writing, speech, and journalism. The curriculum, which includes the English major, consists of 124 hours of coursework. All Baylor teacher education programs lead to certification through the State Board for Educator Certification (SBEC) and the Texas Education Agency (TEA).
Accreditation status: Accredited by Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP). Leads to certification through the State Board for Educator Certification (SBEC) and the Texas Education Agency (TEA).
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Education - Secondary English, Language Arts, and Reading

description: Secondary mathematics teachers are highly sought after in Texas and throughout the United States. You can combine a passion for math with a passion for teaching through Baylor's Secondary Education - Mathematics program. You'll be taught by Baylor faculty with teaching experience in public schools who are experts in their content areas. You'll complete extensive field experiences in diverse school settings, and you'll complete a semester-long clinical teaching experience. The Secondary Education - Mathematics program leads to teacher certification in mathematics for grades 7-12 in Texas and is accredited by the Texas Education Agency. What makes Baylor's Secondary Education - Mathematics program unique? Our graduates are highly sought after because they are well-prepared to be effective teachers. This means that: you will complete extensive field experiences (more than 150 hours) in diverse public school settings across the grades, including a semester-long student teaching internship in an area school. You will receive hands-on training for the use of technology in mathematics instruction and assessment, including calculators, computers, and other forms of technology. You will be taught by nationally recognized mathematics educators with a variety of teaching experience. We offer a secondary math education faculty that has taught in junior high and high school mathematics classrooms. Baylor provides a solid foundation for teaching careers in public and private schools nationwide, and for graduate studies.
Accreditation status: Accredited by the Texas Education Agency
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Education - Secondary Mathematics

description: The mission of Baylor University's secondary education program is to provide a rigorous and comprehensive learning experience that prepares graduates to be knowledgeable, skilled, and reflective practitioners in diverse secondary school settings. Through a commitment to excellence in teaching, scholarship, and service, we cultivate a community of learners dedicated to fostering the intellectual, social, and emotional development of adolescents. The program emphasizes an integrated approach to theory and practice, providing candidates with extensive field experiences and opportunities for collaboration with experienced educators. Graduates are prepared to meet the challenges of 21st-century classrooms, demonstrating pedagogical expertise, technological proficiency, and a commitment to ethical leadership and social justice.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Education - Secondary Science

description: The Bachelor of Science in Education with a major in Secondary Education (Social Studies) is a program designed for students seeking certification to teach Social Studies in grades 7-12. This program integrates rigorous coursework in various social science disciplines (history, political science, economics, geography) with professional education courses focused on pedagogical theory, instructional methods, and practical teaching experiences. Students will develop a deep understanding of social studies content and effective strategies for engaging diverse learners in secondary school settings. The curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, historical analysis, civic engagement, and culturally responsive teaching practices. Graduates are prepared to meet the demands of contemporary classrooms and contribute to the development of informed, active citizens.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Education - Secondary Social Studies

description: The Bachelor of Science in Education (B.S.Ed.) degree with a major in Spanish All-Level (grades EC-12) prepares individuals to teach Spanish in elementary, middle, and high schools. Students completing this degree will be eligible for a Texas teaching certificate in Spanish All-Level upon successful completion of state examinations.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Education - Spanish All Level

description: Special Education (B.S.Ed.) majors are prepared to teach students with disabilities. Coursework provides a strong foundation in theories, principles, and practices related to teaching students across various disability categories (e.g., specific learning disabilities, intellectual disabilities, autism spectrum disorders, emotional disturbance, other health impairments). The curriculum includes field-based experiences in diverse school settings, ensuring practical application of knowledge. Graduates are eligible for Texas Teacher Certification in Special Education EC-12. This program focuses on equipping future educators with the skills to create inclusive learning environments and advocate for the unique needs of exceptional learners.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Education - Special Education

description: The Education minor is for students seeking teacher certification at the secondary level. The Baylor School of Education Secondary Education program provides students with the opportunity to pursue teacher certification alongside a major in another field. Students seeking English as a Second Language (ESL) certification must complete 12 hours of coursework focused on linguistics, ESL methods, and ESL clinical experience. The 12 hours can be completed as part of the 18 hours required for the minor or can be taken in addition to the minor. ESL coursework counts toward the general 18-hour Education minor requirement. This certification is usually coupled with the EC-6 or 4-8 Education minor.
Accreditation status: Baylor University's Educator Preparation Program is accredited by the State Board for Educator Certification (SBEC) and the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).
Program name: Minor in Education Certification - English as a Second Language

description: The Gifted & Talented minor provides an opportunity for students in any major to meet requirements for the Texas supplemental teaching certificate in gifted education. Students complete 18 hours of undergraduate coursework, including three field-based courses, to develop knowledge and skills related to gifted learners. This minor provides a competitive edge for students seeking teaching positions, and also helps to develop a deeper understanding of learners for students seeking other career paths.
Program name: Minor in Education Certification - Gifted & Talented

description: This minor is for students who want to earn Texas teacher certification in Physical Education (EC-12). The teacher certification program offers students seeking a Bachelor’s degree the opportunity to become eligible for initial teacher certification. This minor in Education Certification includes specialized instruction in teaching methods and pedagogical knowledge, along with extensive field experiences and clinical teaching. Certification will be available at the EC-12 (Early Childhood-Grade 12) level.
Program name: Minor in Education Certification - Physical Education

description: The Education Concentration for Biology Majors is an undergraduate pathway designed for students pursuing a Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Biology who are interested in becoming certified teachers. This concentration allows students to fulfill the academic requirements for a B.S. in Biology while simultaneously completing the coursework and field experiences necessary for Texas teacher certification in Life Science (Grades 7-12). Upon successful completion of the program, graduates will be well-prepared to teach biology in secondary schools and will have a strong foundation in both scientific principles and effective pedagogical practices.
Program name: Minor in Education Concentration for Biology Majors

Concentration name: Education Concentration for Health Science Studies Majors
description: Baylor University offers an undergraduate minor in Education for students majoring in Health Science Studies. This minor is offered through the Department of Curriculum & Instruction within the School of Education. The Minor in Education will prepare students for careers in medical and dental education, public health education, and other health professions. This program provides students with practical skills and knowledge in curriculum development, instructional strategies, assessment, and educational leadership within the context of health sciences. Coursework is designed to foster critical thinking, communication, and collaboration skills essential for effective teaching and leadership in healthcare settings. Students will explore diverse educational theories and practices, engaging with topics such as educational technology, inclusive teaching, and ethical considerations in health education. Through a blend of theoretical knowledge and hands-on experiences, students will develop the competencies necessary to excel as educators and leaders in the dynamic field of health sciences. Graduates will be well-equipped to contribute to the advancement of health education, promote health literacy, and inspire future generations of health professionals.
Program name: Minor in Education Concentration for Health Science Studies Majors
Minor in Education Concentration for History Majors

description: This minor prepares students in Arts and Sciences for teacher certification in conjunction with a major in Arts and Sciences.
Accreditation status: The School of Education is accredited by the National Council for Accreditation of Teacher Education (NCATE) and approved by the State Board for Educator Certification (SBEC).
Program name: Minor in Education Concentration for Math Majors

description: The educational psychology minor is designed for undergraduate students who wish to supplement their major by learning about human development, learning, and motivation. It is designed to prepare students to apply psychological principles to educational contexts and to pursue careers in a wide range of fields, including teaching, counseling, social work, and human resources. The minor can also be beneficial for students considering graduate study in education or psychology.
Program name: Minor in Educational Psychology

description: The Educational Studies minor is designed for students seeking to gain a foundational understanding of the field of education for a variety of purposes. The minor offers insight into the role of education in society, learning theories and their application in diverse contexts, and the historical and philosophical underpinnings of educational practices. This minor is suitable for students who are exploring career paths in education, wish to enhance their primary degree with educational knowledge, or simply have a personal interest in understanding how learning and educational systems function. It provides a robust theoretical framework applicable to a wide array of professional fields beyond traditional teaching, including corporate training, educational policy, non-profit work, and community development.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Education in Educational Studies

description: Electrical and computer engineering is a broad field focusing on the design, development, and application of electrical, electronic, and computer systems. It encompasses areas like signal processing, control systems, telecommunications, microelectronics, computer architecture, software development, and robotics. This degree program prepares students to innovate and solve complex problems across various industries, from aerospace and automotive to healthcare and consumer electronics. The Electrical and Computer Engineering program focuses on both hardware and software aspects, giving students a well-rounded education in both areas. Students will delve into topics such as circuit design, digital systems, embedded systems, programming languages, and network systems. This major provides a strong foundation in mathematics, physics, and computer science principles, essential for understanding and advancing technology. Graduates are well-equipped for roles in research and development, design, testing, manufacturing, and systems integration.
Accreditation status: The Electrical and Computer Engineering program at Baylor University is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Electrical and Computer Engineering

description: The Bachelor of Science in Engineering (BSE) degree program at Baylor University offers a broad, integrated engineering education that provides students with a strong foundation in core engineering principles while also offering flexibility to specialize in areas of interest. The BSE program is designed to develop Christian servant-leaders who are committed to applying engineering principles to solve challenging problems throughout the world. The curriculum provides a strong foundation in mathematics, basic sciences, and engineering fundamentals, along with hands-on laboratory experiences and design projects. Students develop problem-solving, critical thinking, and communication skills, preparing them for successful careers in diverse engineering fields or for advanced graduate studies. The program emphasizes ethical considerations, global perspectives, and social responsibility in engineering practice, aligning with Baylor’s mission of educating students for worldwide leadership and service.
Accreditation status: Accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Engineering
Bachelor of Arts in English

description: The Minor in English is designed for students who are majoring in other areas and wish to broaden their knowledge and appreciation of literary texts, critical methods, and cultural history.
Program name: Minor in English

description: Baylor's Hankamer School of Business prepares students to launch and manage businesses by cultivating an entrepreneurial mindset and providing a comprehensive understanding of business creation, innovation, and growth strategies. Through hands-on learning, students develop essential skills in leadership, problem-solving, and strategic thinking, enabling them to pursue their entrepreneurial aspirations, innovate within existing corporations, or lead social ventures. The program emphasizes ethical decision-making, global awareness, and the integration of faith and business principles, preparing graduates to make a positive impact in the world.
Accreditation status: AACSB International – The Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business
Program name: Bachelor of Business Administration in Entrepreneurship and Corporate Innovation

description: Environmental health science is an interdisciplinary field devoted to understanding and improving the health of humans and the environment. Environmental health scientists are concerned with the complex relationships between the physical, chemical, and biological environment and human health. The Bachelor of Science in Environmental Health Science program at Baylor provides students with a strong foundation in environmental science, toxicology, risk assessment, environmental law, and public health. Students learn to identify, assess, and control environmental factors that can potentially affect health. The curriculum integrates scientific principles with practical applications, preparing students for careers in environmental protection, public health agencies, industry, research, and further graduate studies. Graduates will be equipped to address pressing environmental challenges and contribute to creating healthier communities and ecosystems.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Environmental Health Science

description: The Minor in Environmental Humanities aims to bring humanistic inquiry to bear on the myriad environmental issues facing humanity. Students completing the minor will learn to: Understand the historical, philosophical, and cultural dimensions of environmental problems. Analyze environmental issues through diverse interpretive frameworks, including literary, ethical, and historical perspectives. Communicate effectively about environmental topics across different audiences and disciplines. Engage critically with contemporary environmental debates and propose solutions informed by humanistic insights. The Environmental Humanities minor is an interdisciplinary program designed for students across all majors who wish to deepen their understanding of environmental issues from a humanities perspective. The minor complements scientific and policy-oriented environmental studies by providing a robust foundation in the cultural, ethical, and historical dimensions of environmental thought and action.
Program name: Minor in Environmental Humanities

description: Environmental science is the study of the environment and the solution of environmental problems. Baylor’s undergraduate program in environmental science provides students with a strong scientific background along with an understanding of human interactions with the environment and environmental policy. Students completing the program are prepared for a variety of entry-level positions in government and industry, as well as for graduate study in environmental science and related fields. The program is inherently interdisciplinary, involving courses and faculty from biology, chemistry, geology, and environmental science. A key feature of the program is hands-on research and field experience, including opportunities to conduct research with faculty mentors and to gain practical experience through internships.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Environmental Science

description: The Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Environmental Studies combines a solid understanding of environmental science with the critical thinking, communication, and problem-solving skills of a liberal arts education. This degree is designed for students interested in a broad interdisciplinary approach to environmental issues, preparing them for a wide range of careers in policy, law, journalism, business, and non-profit organizations. Students will explore the scientific principles underlying environmental problems, as well as the social, economic, ethical, and political dimensions of these issues. The curriculum emphasizes analytical skills, research methods, and effective communication to address complex environmental challenges from multiple perspectives.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Environmental Studies

description: The Environmental Studies minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a broad exposure to environmental issues and how they are addressed through a variety of disciplines.
Program name: Minor in Environmental Studies

description: The minor in Ethnic Studies gives students an understanding of issues affecting ethnic minorities in the United States and abroad. With faculty from across the university, the program is broadly interdisciplinary, offering courses from departments as diverse as English, Political Science, Religion, Sociology, and Modern Foreign Languages. By exploring the cultures, histories, and social conditions of different racial and ethnic groups, students gain a deeper understanding of issues such as race, ethnicity, inequality, and social justice. The minor provides an excellent foundation for any student interested in careers in social justice, advocacy, community organizing, public policy, and education.
Program name: Minor in Ethnic Studies

description: This degree provides students with a strong scientific background in the study of human movement and the physiological adaptations to exercise. The curriculum prepares students for careers in clinical and research settings as well as graduate programs in exercise physiology, physical therapy, occupational therapy, physician assistant, and medical school. The program provides the foundational science and physiology courses typically required for admission to professional and graduate programs in the allied health sciences.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Exercise Physiology

Concentration name: Child and Family Studies, Family and Consumer Sciences General, Family and Consumer Sciences Secondary Education, Fashion Design, Fashion Merchandising, Interior Design, Waco Family and Consumer Sciences Internship Program
description: Family and Consumer Sciences (FCS) is a broad and dynamic field focused on improving the well-being of individuals, families, and communities. The FCS program at Baylor University provides students with a strong academic foundation and practical skills to address real-world challenges related to family life, child development, consumer economics, nutrition, housing, textiles, and fashion. Our curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, problem-solving, and ethical decision-making, preparing graduates for diverse careers in education, social services, business, and design. Through hands-on experiences, research opportunities, and community engagement, students gain a holistic understanding of how individuals and families function within society. The program fosters leadership qualities and a commitment to service, empowering students to make a positive impact on the lives of others.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Family & Consumer Sciences

description: The Bachelor of Arts in Film & Digital Media provides students with a broad and deep understanding of the history, theory, and criticism of film, television, and digital media. The curriculum is designed to balance critical studies with hands-on production experiences that prepare students to become creative, ethical, and critically engaged media professionals. The FDM major offers a flexible curriculum that allows students to explore their interests in various aspects of the film and digital media industry through one of four concentrations: Documentary; Film & Creative Production; Media & Strategic Communication; or Screenwriting.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Film and Digital Media

description: The minor in Film Theory and Criticism is designed to provide students with a deep understanding of film as an art form and cultural phenomenon. Students will explore various theoretical approaches to film analysis, engage in critical discussions of cinematic techniques, and develop sophisticated skills in interpreting and evaluating films from diverse historical and cultural contexts. This minor is ideal for students who wish to enhance their analytical abilities, broaden their cultural literacy, and prepare for careers in fields such as film criticism, academia, archives, or arts administration.
Program name: Minor in Film Theory and Criticism

description: As a finance major, you'll delve into the fascinating world of financial markets and institutions, investments, and corporate finance. Finance impacts every aspect of the global economy, making it a critical field of study. Graduates with a finance degree are well-equipped for a wide range of careers in corporate financial management, investments, and banking. The BBA in Finance curriculum includes general business courses, foundational finance courses, and electives. You will develop analytical, problem-solving, and decision-making skills that are highly valued in the financial industry. You can also tailor your studies to your interests through concentrations in Corporate Finance & Investments, Financial Planning, or Commercial Banking.
Accreditation status: Accredited by AACSB International, the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business.
Program name: Bachelor of Business Administration in Finance

description: The Forensic Science minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a basic understanding of scientific methods as they apply to law. The minor focuses on the application of biological, chemical, and physical sciences to criminal and civil laws. Through your coursework, you will learn the scientific principles and techniques used to analyze and interpret physical evidence for legal purposes. This minor complements a wide variety of majors, including Biology, Chemistry, Criminal Justice, Forensic Anthropology, and Psychology.
Program name: Minor in Forensic Science

description: Baylor's French program provides you with the skills to read, write and speak French, as well as an understanding of French culture, literature and history. As you progress through the program, you'll engage in a wide range of topics, including French civilization, literature, culture, history, cinema, theatre and art. Your coursework will emphasize communication skills and a critical understanding of the French-speaking world. You'll gain valuable experience through study abroad, internships, undergraduate research and opportunities to interact with native speakers. The French major prepares students for a wide range of careers, including international business, government, foreign service, law, journalism, teaching, translation and graduate study. You can also combine a French major with a major or minor in another field, such as business, history, political science or art.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in French
Minor in French

description: The Bachelor of Science (B.S.) degree in Geosciences is designed for students seeking a strong scientific and technical background in the earth sciences. This program provides comprehensive preparation for careers in environmental industries, natural resource exploration and management, geological surveying, and hydrologic sciences. It also serves as an excellent foundation for graduate studies in a variety of geoscience fields. Students will develop a deep understanding of Earth’s processes, materials, and history, as well as the interactions between human activity and the environment. The curriculum emphasizes hands-on experience through laboratory work, field trips, and research opportunities. Key areas of study include mineralogy, petrology, structural geology, paleontology, geomorphology, hydrogeology, and environmental geology. Graduates are equipped with critical thinking, problem-solving, and analytical skills essential for addressing complex geological and environmental challenges.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Geosciences

description: Students in the German program immerse themselves in a fascinating culture, develop strong proficiency in the German language, and prepare for careers in an increasingly globalized world. The German program offers courses in German language, literature, culture, and linguistics. Baylor also offers two courses in German film (FL 3307 and FL 4307) which may be applied to the German major or minor. As a vital part of the curriculum, students are strongly encouraged to participate in a study abroad program, either during the summer or a semester.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in German

description: The study of German language and culture gives students insights into the culture of one of the world’s most important economic, political, and cultural countries. German is not only spoken in Germany, but also in Austria, Switzerland, Luxembourg, and Liechtenstein, and it is the most widely spoken language in the European Union. Many students study German because of its importance for international business, engineering, science, or music. Students can also combine a German Minor with their Major in many other disciplines, for example, Political Science, Art History, or International Studies. Students also develop critical thinking skills and learn to communicate effectively and appropriately in German, which will enrich their professional and personal lives.
Program name: Minor in German

description: The Gerontology minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to provide students with a broad understanding of the aging process, older adults, and their social, psychological, and physiological needs. The program fosters critical thinking about challenges and opportunities related to an aging society. Courses in the minor focus on topics such as health and wellness in later life, social policies affecting older adults, age-friendly communities, and the psychology of aging.
Program name: Minor in Gerontology

description: The Great Texts major at Baylor is a multi-disciplinary program in the humanities that leads to a Bachelor of Arts degree. Students read and discuss the most important works of the Western intellectual and literary tradition. From Homer to Augustine, from Dante to Shakespeare, from Galileo to Nietzsche, the program explores a wide range of texts that have shaped Western civilization. Through rigorous study and lively discussion, students develop critical thinking, analytical reasoning, and communication skills necessary for a lifetime of learning and leadership. The program provides a solid foundation for careers in law, business, education, ministry, and public service, as well as for graduate study in a variety of fields.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Great Texts of the Western Tradition

description: The Minor in Great Texts of the Western Tradition introduces students to the foundational works of Western thought and culture. Through close reading and critical discussion of texts from ancient Greece to the present day, students in the Great Texts minor engage with the enduring questions of human existence and the development of Western intellectual tradition. The minor complements any major by cultivating skills in analytical thinking, persuasive writing, and informed interpretation, preparing students for a wide range of academic and professional paths.
Program name: Minor in Great Texts of the Western Tradition

description: The Department of Classics offers an 18-hour undergraduate minor for students who wish to supplement their major by focusing on the ancient world, particularly Greek and Roman language, literature, history, and culture. The minor requires a sequence of two courses in either Greek or Latin at the 3000- or 4000-level, plus three additional courses in Classics (at least 6 hours must be at the 3000- or 4000-level). This minor is an excellent option for students seeking to deepen their understanding of foundational cultures, languages, and literatures relevant to many fields, including law, medicine, theology, and the humanities.
Program name: Minor in Greek

description: From Homer's epics to the Roman Empire, the study of Greek and Roman civilizations encompasses the origins of Western culture, providing insights into literature, philosophy, history, politics, and art. The Greek and Roman Studies B.A. program provides a comprehensive understanding of these foundational cultures. You’ll explore classical languages, literature, history, and archaeology, developing critical thinking, analytical, and communication skills applicable to a wide range of careers.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Greek and Roman Studies

Concentration name: Pre-Physical Therapy, Pre-Occupational Therapy, Pre-Physician Assistant, Pre-Medical, Pre-Dental, Pre-Chiropractic, Pre-Optometry, Pre-Podiatry, Health Professions, Public Health, Pre-Athletic Training
description: The Bachelor of Science in Health Science Studies offers students the flexibility to prepare for various careers related to health, as well as graduate and professional programs. The rigorous coursework is designed to provide students with the necessary foundation in biological and physical sciences, mathematics, statistics, and social sciences. Students are required to take courses in human anatomy, physiology, nutrition, and exercise physiology. Students choose one of the program's emphasis areas that align with their career goals. Some of these areas provide an excellent curriculum for students to be competitive applicants for professional programs such as physical therapy, occupational therapy, physician assistant, medical, dental, chiropractic, optometry, and podiatry. Other areas prepare students for careers in community health, public health, health and fitness, and health administration.
